addText.text: Dear participant, Welcome to our study! We are the Crossmodal Research Laboratory, Department of Experimental Psychology, Oxford University. We are interested in understanding how people associate information across the senses. 'If you decide to take part in this experiment, you will be asked to state your liking of certain food products, as well as to provide us with some information about yourself. There are not right or wrong responses, please respond according to what it feels right to you. We hope you enjoy it. Your participation is very important to us.
When the stimuli have loaded (below bar), please click 'Continue'

Please read the below consent statement and indicate whether you consent. {u}Statement of Informed Consent{/u} - I have read and understood the information above, and understand the general purpose of the experiment - I understand that I can withdraw during the study without giving a reason and that by doing so, we will destroy your data. (NB - Please be aware that the data we collect is anonymous - if you decide you do not want your data in the study after giving your final consent, we will be unable to trace your specific data to remove it) - I understand my responses are anonymous - I agree to take part in this online experiment - I agree to the University of Oxford keeping and processing the data I have provided during the course of this study. By clicking ‘I consent’, you are agreeing to the above statements.

addText.text: These dishes are a variant of one currently served in a fine dining restaurant. Please imagine you are in such a restaurant. Which would you be willing to pay more for? Please click the dish you would pay more for first and the dish you would pay less for second.---How much in US dollars would you be willing to pay for it?
Please rotate the food so that it is orientated so it looks most appealing by moving your mouse around the food. Press SPACE when you are done.

Thanks for taking part in this study. We're exploring how different ways of arranging the elements of a dish on a plate can have an effect on its perceived enjoyment and your expectations regarding food. In previous studies, we found that the visual aspects of plating can have an effect on people's perception of the flavour of the food and on consumption behaviour. People also appear to pay more for food if presented symmetrically on a plate, rather than asymmetrically. Still, we don't know what the effect is of the orientation of the elements on a plate (pointing downwards rather than left, for instance) on people's liking of the presentation. This is what you helped us assessing by taking part to this online experiment.
If you have any questions or would like to here more about our research, please contact us at andy.woods@xperiment.mobi DO NOT FORGET TO ENTER THE BELOW CODE INTO MECHANICAL TURK.
